description.narrative: The Humanitarian Country Team has launched a Disaster Response Plan to provide life-saving assistance and recovery services to 13,100 affected people in Sanamxay District.

activity-description.narrative: The project supports flood recovery in Attapeu province

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1. Number of affected communities receiving further education and preventive measures on the dislodged Unexploded Ordnance (UXO) after the floods. 2. Number of communities benefiting from cash for work for livelihoods restoration, restoration of community infrastructure or cash for work for economic recovery. 3. Number of community members receiving legal supports for grievances, resettlement and other matters. 4. Number of community members from 5 ethnic groups receiving information through radio and being involved in the radio programme. 5. Number of villages forming village disaster management committees and number of communities receiving early warning information through mobile phone in partnership with the communication and coordination role of the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare

comment.narrative: 1. The eight villages most affected by the flood in Sanamxay district, Attapeu province are all contaminated with UXO, including cluster munitions. There is risk that other villages could be further contaminated after the floods. 2. The displaced households are in temporary shelters, no longer have access to livelihoods. Subsistence farming households have been hit hard with loss of income after their crops damaged by the floods. In addition, most of the community infrastructures were damaged. 3. Community’s access to legal services is very limited in rural areas, especially after such big emergency 4. Non-existence of community radio in the affected provinces. 5. High number of mobile phone usage and subscription in rural areas and the Ministry’s role and responsibility in providing information public and in coordination roles.

1. Affected communities from 13 villages, i.e. - Ban Tae - Ban Xay Don Kong - Ban Hin Lad - Ban Tha Sang Jan - Ban Tha Hin - Ban Samongtai - Ban Mai - Ban Pindong - Ban Phonsa-art - Ban Nong care - Ban Sam Oi - Ban Had Udomxa 2. Around 1000 communities from the 13 affected villages will be selected after consultation with government and field assessment and will have focus on the elderly, people with disabilities and reduced mobility, single-headed female households, lactating women, 3. Community from 13 affected villages. 4. Community members from the affected areas would benefit from access to information, including involvement in the radio programme, broadcasted in 5 ethnic languages: Alak; Taoy; Suay, and Lavenh) 5. Communities from 13 affected villages would benefit from receiving alert for possible extreme hydrometeorological event as well as access to information and coordination.

In Attapeu Province, all the 13 affected villages benefited from community radio services broadcasted in 5 ethnic languages including support from the Legal Aid Office in Sanamxay District. The handover of Early Warning Equipment in Dongbak Village Camp, Sanamxai district: UNDP in partnership with the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare (MLSW) pilot-tested the forecasting and early warning alert systems administered by the Department of Meteorology and Hydrology (DMH) of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment and the Ministry of Post and Telecommunication and the four private sector telecommunications providers (Lao Telecom, ETL, Beeline and UNITEL). The internally displaced persons camp ‘Dongbak Village Camp’ is comprised of three villages and 996 displaced persons.
The IDP’s had been in the camp for close to 9 months since the flood incidence in Sanamxai district July/August/September 2018. Almost all the houses in that community collapsed and dilapidated due to the impact of the flash floods.
